conclusion: Analyze forces acting on plank and block to determine condition for F1.
Weight of block mg acts downward.
Normal force N acts perpendicular to plank.
Frictional force f acts opposite to direction of motion.
Applied forces F1 and F2: F1 acts horizontally left, F2 acts vertically upward.
Maximum static frictional force is f_max = mu N.
Use f = mu N since maximum static friction equals kinetic friction.
Normal force N is due to block's weight component perpendicular to plank: N = mg cos(theta).
For plank to move upward, vertical component of forces must be greater than plank's weight: F2 + f sin(theta) > Mg.
Horizontal force F1 affects normal force and frictional force; horizontal component of forces must balance: F1 = N sin(theta) + f cos(theta).
Substitute N and f into equations: N = mg cos(theta), f = mu mg cos(theta).
Condition for plank to move upward: F2 + mu mg cos(theta) sin(theta) > Mg.
Simplify condition using trigonometric identities: sin(theta) cos(theta) = 1/2 sin(2theta).
Condition becomes: F2 + 1/2 mu mg sin(2theta) > Mg.
Determine F1 to ensure horizontal forces balance: F1 = mg cos(theta) sin(theta) + mu mg cos^2(theta).
Final condition for F1: F1 > mg cos(theta) sin(theta) + mu mg cos^2(theta).
Conclusion: F1 must satisfy F1 > mg cos(theta) sin(theta) + mu mg cos^2(theta) to ensure plank moves upward.
